hero.title: Vanilla Hytale Servers
hero.description: A curated vanilla Hytale server list with five editor-ranked picks. Discover the best vanilla Hytale servers for SMP and survival, compare rules and gameplay footprint, check monetization and no pay-to-win notes, and copy the Hytale server IP to join. Every listing includes an editor score, a last-checked date, and a clear review of what stays vanilla and what is changed. When players search for vanilla Hytale servers, they usually want the real experience: explore, gather, craft, and build, without mods replacing survival. This list focuses on vanilla-first servers and clearly documents each server’s gameplay footprint so you can pick the right vanilla Hytale server fast.

items.title: Peaceful Vanilla Club (Hytale)
items.subtitle: Peaceful vanilla survival SMP with a semi-vanilla approach: no grief, no random PvP, no pay to win.

details.title: Vanilla purity
details.content:
The server aims to keep the survival loop intact: explore, gather, craft, build, and collaborate, without systems that replace the world with menus. It describes itself as semi-vanilla: minimal quality-of-life choices plus strict moderation to protect builders and long-term projects, while keeping progression meaningful.

  • No fast-travel spam designed to replace exploration and distance.
  • One shared survival world optimized for long-term towns and community infrastructure.
  • Changes are introduced slowly, with stability prioritized over hype.

details.title: Rules and moderation
details.content:
The rule set is built around a peaceful world: no griefing, no stealing, and no unsolicited PvP. The goal is that your builds and towns survive when you log off. Moderation is strict against harassment, slurs, and exploit abuse.

  • No griefing or sabotage (protects towns and long-term builds).
  • No random PvP in the open world (events, if any, should be opt-in and clearly separated).
  • Clear community standards to keep chat and gameplay calm.

details.title: Fair play and monetization
details.content:
The server’s public messaging is explicit: no pay-to-win. No selling power, progression, donor kits, boosts, or shortcuts that break survival balance. If donations exist, they should support operations without affecting gameplay.

  • No progression advantages sold for money.
  • No paid shortcuts that invalidate exploration or early survival progression.
  • Fair survival balance to protect any organic community economy.

details.title: Stability and last checked
details.content:
The community positions itself as long-running (since 2019) and operations-focused, with monitoring and backups as part of the long-term plan. “Last checked” reflects our most recent verification of join info and listing details.

  • Long-term world mindset: persistent progress over fast seasons.
  • Operational focus: monitoring and backups to support stability.
  • For the latest join steps, the Discord pinned instructions remain the source of truth.

details.title: Community and onboarding
details.content:
Onboarding is intentionally simple: Discord is the hub for announcements, rules, support, and connection steps. The culture is builder-friendly and relaxed, with a focus on cooperative projects, towns, and exploration.

  • Join Discord first, read rules, then connect using the pinned steps.
  • Inclusive, LGBTQ+ friendly community positioning.
  • Designed to be stress-free: log in, make progress, log out without drama.

details.title: Transparency
details.content:
The server’s messaging is clear about what it is optimizing for (peaceful survival) and what it avoids (pay-to-win, unsolicited PvP, fast travel spam). Any semi-vanilla choices should be disclosed in a way that stays readable for real players.

  • Explicit positioning: no grief, no unsolicited PvP, no pay-to-win.
  • Semi-vanilla intent stated: protect the experience without rewriting it.
  • Discord-first approach for current connection info and announcements.

methodology.title: How scoring works
methodology.description: The editor score is a simple sum. Each category is scored from 0 up to its maximum points, then we add them together to get a final score out of 100. The sections inside each server card mirror these same categories, so the rubric and the review topics match one to one. For vanilla Hytale servers, scoring rewards small gameplay footprint, transparent rules, and fair monetization, so “vanilla-first” stays meaningful. Scores are refreshed when a listing is re-checked, so the score and the “last checked” date are designed to stay aligned. A high score is about clarity and restraint, not popularity.
exclusionRules: No pay-to-win: no progression advantages sold for money.
Clear vanilla-first statement: changes and additions must be disclosed.
Public rules: griefing, PvP, resets, and moderation expectations.
Contact exists: at least an active Discord or website.
Verifiable access: IP and availability can be checked (we show “last checked”).

faq.title: Vanilla Hytale server FAQ
faq.description: Definitions stay simple on purpose, so “vanilla” remains useful as a label and not just a marketing word. If you are comparing vanilla Hytale servers, focus on gameplay footprint and fairness, then verify rules and monetization before you join. The goal is that you can read a server card fast and understand what is preserved, what is moderated, and what is changed. If a listing is vague about rules or monetization, treat it as unverified until it is clarified.

items.question: What is a vanilla Hytale server?
items.answer: A vanilla Hytale server focuses on base gameplay and avoids changes that significantly alter progression, balance, loot, or economy. Some servers may still run minimal quality-of-life and moderation tooling, as long as it is disclosed and does not rewrite the core experience.

items.question: Vanilla vs semi-vanilla
items.answer: Semi-vanilla usually adds convenience systems. In this vanilla Hytale servers list, we prefer vanilla-first servers and we document any gameplay footprint clearly per server.

items.question: Do you accept pay-to-win servers?
items.answer: No. Pay-to-win fails the exclusion rules and is not listed.

items.question: How do you verify a server is vanilla-first?
items.answer: We look for a clear vanilla-first statement, public rules, a monetization policy, and a gameplay footprint that does not replace core survival with menus and paid shortcuts. We also track a last-checked date for join info and listing details.

items.question: What is Hytale in simple terms?
items.answer: Hytale is a sandbox adventure game built to support both vanilla gameplay and deep modding. That is why the vanilla-first label matters: it signals servers that try to keep the base survival loop intact.

items.question: Who runs this site?
items.answer: VanillaHytaleServers.com is curated by editors who also run a vanilla server directory for Minecraft: vanillaminecraftservers.net. The goal is clarity and comparability for players searching for vanilla Hytale servers.

items.question: Can I suggest a server?
items.answer: Yes. Send the server name, IP, region, language, and links to rules and monetization policy. If it passes the exclusion rules, we review it for a chance to be featured here.
